title: Wishless
data:
A **wishless** character is a character who [ascends](/wiki/Ascend "Ascend") without using any [wishes](/wiki/Wish "Wish"). The main challenge in such a game is to assemble a complete [ascension kit](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit"), or enough parts thereof, without the benefit of wishing for any items that one may lack.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Playing wishless](#Playing_wishless)

  - [1.1 Polypiling](#Polypiling)
  - [1.2 Magic resistance](#Magic_resistance)
  - [1.3 Bag of holding](#Bag_of_holding)
  - [1.4 Reflection](#Reflection)
  - [1.5 Levitation](#Levitation)
  - [1.6 How to kill the Wizard](#How_to_kill_the_Wizard)

- [2 Accidental loss of conduct](#Accidental_loss_of_conduct)

- [3 References](#References)

## Playing wishless

In a typical game, a character will always have access to at least five wishes from the [wand of wishing](/wiki/Wand_of_wishing "Wand of wishing") located in the [castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle"). In a wishless game, the character voluntarily avoids using wishes and thus needs to obtain the corresponding items some other way. What follows is a description of some techniques that one can use in the absence of a wish. Note that it is rare for a wishless character to accomplish all of the goals outlined below. Part of the challenge of playing a wishless character is to ascend successfully despite missing one or two components that a typical, non-wishless character would possess.

11.5% of all winning players on [NAO](/wiki/NAO "NAO") have a wishless ascension, and 72.5% artifact-wishless.

### Polypiling

Most items in an [ascension kit](/wiki/Ascension_kit "Ascension kit") can be obtained one way or another via [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling"). In the absence of wishes, polypiling is even more useful than usual, and it is a good technique to employ for those who are not simultaneously attempting the [never polymorph an object](/wiki/Never_polymorph_an_object "Never polymorph an object") conduct.

The problem with polypiling is that it requires either a wand of polymorph, or a spellbook of polymorph and a spellcasting character. Neither item is easy to obtain without wishes. The spellbook is slightly easier to obtain, since spellbooks can sometimes be granted to you as a gift while [praying](/wiki/Pray "Pray") to your god. [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") with good [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck") have a high chance of successfully writing a spellbook of polymorph, provided they have a sufficiently-charged [magic marker](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker").

### Magic resistance

One of the most common targets for a wish is [gray dragon scale mail](/wiki/Gray_dragon_scale_mail "Gray dragon scale mail") or some other item granting magic resistance. With no wishes, magic resistance must be obtained some other way. One way of course is to kill a [gray dragon](/wiki/Gray_dragon "Gray dragon") and hope that it leaves behind [gray dragon scales](/wiki/Gray_dragon_scales "Gray dragon scales"). A character can increase their chances of success by [reverse genociding](/wiki/Reverse_genocide "Reverse genocide") gray dragons, or using a method of [revival](/wiki/Revive "Revive") to repeatedly kill a gray dragon until it leaves scales. Another good method to spawn dragons is confused [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") looting.

Another easy way to get magic resistance is to play a character that starts with magic resistance or whose [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact") provides magic resistance. [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") start with a [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") and can easily get [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane") from an altar. [Archaeologists](/wiki/Archaeologist "Archaeologist"), [Cavemen](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), [Monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), [Tourists](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"), and [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") have quest artifacts which provide magic resistance. In most cases, it is not recommended for characters to rely on their quest artifact as their sole source of magic resistance, because quest artifacts can be stolen by the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor"). However, wishless characters in general have fewer options than non-wishless characters, and oftentimes must resort to such suboptimal play.

A [cloak of magic resistance](/wiki/Cloak_of_magic_resistance "Cloak of magic resistance") is arguably the most desirable source of magic resistance, but it is difficult to obtain for characters other than [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard"), even with [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling"), because it is the rarest of the randomly occurring cloaks. Aside from bones piles of Wizard characters, the best sources of cloaks of magic resistance are [aligned priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest"), who are guaranteed to be present in [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") and the [Valley of the Dead](/wiki/Valley_of_the_Dead "Valley of the Dead"). You can use a [wand of probing](/wiki/Wand_of_probing "Wand of probing") to detect whether or not a priest has a cloak of magic resistance; doing so will not anger the priest. Priests without a cloak of magic resistance will have some other good cloak instead, and may be worth killing anyway for their cloak.

### Bag of holding

A [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding") can be found half of the time in [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban "Sokoban"). If one does not find a bag of holding in Sokoban, it can be difficult to get one. One option is to [polypile](/wiki/Polypile "Polypile") magical [tools](/wiki/Tool "Tool") such as [unicorn horns](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn") and hope that one of them turns into a bag of holding.

Many wishless ascensions never result in the character finding a bag of holding. In this situation, a character must incur the extra inventory management challenge associated with ascending using a [sack](/wiki/Sack "Sack").

### Reflection

An [amulet of reflection](/wiki/Amulet_of_reflection "Amulet of reflection") is available half of the time in Sokoban. Alternatively, [Perseus](/wiki/Perseus "Perseus")'s statue sometimes contains a [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection"). Other common sources of shields of reflection are [Angels](/wiki/Angel "Angel") and [Aleaxes](/wiki/Aleax "Aleax"). [Silver dragon scale mail](/wiki/Silver_dragon_scale_mail "Silver dragon scale mail") is another possible option. Like [gray dragon scale mail](/wiki/Gray_dragon_scale_mail "Gray dragon scale mail"), it can be obtained by reverse genociding [silver dragons](/wiki/Silver_dragon "Silver dragon") or using [revival](/wiki/Revive "Revive") on a silver dragon corpse.

A character without reflection faces three major hazards: disintegration blasts from [black dragons](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon"), [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death") zaps (if you also lack magic resistance) and [lightning](/wiki/Lightning "Lightning") attacks which can explode wands and rings in the character's main [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory"). If reflection cannot be obtained, it is recommended to minimize the number of wands and rings in your main inventory, and keep ample supplies of spare wands and rings available in your [bag](/wiki/Bag "Bag"). Players getting a single genocide from a [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") might consider genociding black dragons, but if you have a scroll, it is better used to reverse genocide silver dragons.

### Levitation

Having some form of [levitation](/wiki/Levitation "Levitation") is desirable in the [End Game](/wiki/End_Game "End Game"). [Perseus](/wiki/Perseus "Perseus")'s statue sometimes contains levitation boots. If no other means of levitation is available, a blessed [potion of levitation](/wiki/Potion_of_levitation "Potion of levitation") lasts for at least 250 turns, and potions of levitation are common enough that one can usually assemble a large stack of them by the end of the game. One blessed potion is more than enough to carry you through the [Endgame](/wiki/Endgame "Endgame") if you don't procrastinate, and the [water walking boots](/wiki/Water_walking_boots "Water walking boots") in [Vlad's Tower](/wiki/Vlad%27s_Tower "Vlad's Tower") take care of everything before that.

### How to kill the Wizard

Most characters kill the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") using death rays from [wands of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death"), and re[charge](/wiki/Charge "Charge") the wands enough times to ascend. A wishless character cannot wish for [magic markers](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker"), and thus may have a hard time getting enough [scrolls of charging](/wiki/Scroll_of_charging "Scroll of charging") to recharge wands. For this reason, it is common for wishless characters to polymorph into a [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice") and lay a large number of cockatrice [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg") for use as stoning weapons against the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor").

Cockatrice eggs are also useful against [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus"), to kill him before he uses up any charges from the [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death") that he always carries. If you are low on wand of death charges, use cockatrice eggs to kill the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor"), and save the wands of death for use against the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders").

## Accidental loss of conduct

It is nearly impossible to accidentally lose the wishless conduct in NetHack 3.4.3. If the game bestows an unwanted wish (for example, from quaffing a [smoky potion](/wiki/Smoky_potion "Smoky potion")), you can answer *nothing*, *nil*, or *none*[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) in order to avoid using a wish.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [objnam.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 1808](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/objnam.c#line1808 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/objnam.c")
